arm_group.description: Patients that received the standard consent with signed consent form

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a prospective cohort study in which the standard verbal informed consent process for
      ketamine sedation is compared to a multimedia informed consent process. The goals include
      determining if parents prefer a multimedia consent process and evaluating the effectiveness
      of multimedia consent process.

clinical_study.brief_title: Use of a Multimedia Presentation for Informed Consent

detailed_description.textblock:
BACKGROUND:  Informed consent (IC) is an ethical process for ensuring patient autonomy.
      Multimedia presentations (MMP) often aid the IC process for research studies.  Thus, it
      follows that MMP would improve IC in clinical settings.

      OBJECTIVE:  To determine if MMP for the IC process for ketamine sedation improves parental
      satisfaction and comprehension as compared to standard practice.

      DESIGN/METHODS: This two phase study compared two methods of IC for ketamine sedation of
      pediatric patients.  Phase one was a randomized, prospective study that compared the
      standard verbal consent to a MMP.  Phase two implemented the MMP into daily work flow.
      Parents completed a survey evaluating their satisfaction of the IC process and assessing
      their knowledge of ketamine sedation.  Primary outcome measures were parental overall
      satisfaction with the IC process and knowledge of ketamine sedation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Receiving ketamine sedation for fracture reduction

          -  Less than 18 years of age

          -  English as primary language

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  patients who received medications in addition to ketamine for sedation

          -  Families where English was not the primary language

intervention.description: PowerPoint presentation created with approval of section of emergency medicine for informed consent for ketamine sedation

clinical_study.official_title: Use of a Multimedia Presentation to Enhance the Informed Consent for Ketamine Sedation in a Pediatric Emergency Department

overall_official.affiliation: Nationwide Childrens, Department of Emergency Medicine

primary_outcome.description: Parents are given a survey with a 5-point Likert scale to evaluated their satisfaction with the informed consent process
primary_outcome.measure: Parents' satisfaction with the informed consent process

primary_outcome.description: The parents are give a multiple choice quiz on the information present on ketamine sedation
primary_outcome.measure: The parent's knowledge of ketamine sedation.

reference.citation: Akkad A, Jackson C, Kenyon S, Dixon-Woods M, Taub N, Habiba M. Informed consent for elective and emergency surgery: questionnaire study. BJOG. 2004 Oct;111(10):1133-8.

Baren J, Campbell CF, Schears RM, Shofer FS, Datner EM, Hollander JE. Observed behaviors of subjects during informed consent for an emergency department study. Ann Emerg Med. 2010 Jan;55(1):9-14. doi: 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2009.09.023. Epub 2009 Nov 22.
Agre P, Rapkin B. Improving informed consent: a comparison of four consent tools. IRB. 2003 Nov-Dec;25(6):1-7.
Flory J, Emanuel E. Interventions to improve research participants' understanding in informed consent for research: a systematic review. JAMA. 2004 Oct 6;292(13):1593-601. Review.

Nwomeh BC, Hayes J, Caniano DA, Upperman JS, Kelleher KJ. A parental educational intervention to facilitate informed consent for emergency operations in children. J Surg Res. 2009 Apr;152(2):258-63. doi: 10.1016/j.jss.2008.01.008. Epub 2008 Feb 4.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: The satisfaction questions on the survey are divided into groups addressing the four key elements of informed consent: beneficence, maleficence, content, and assent.
The survey and quiz results are compared depending on demographics
secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of satisfaction and knowledge with demographics

secondary_outcome.description: Provider satisfaction was collected using a Likert scale at the time the presentation was embedded into the computer order entry system.  They were re-surveyed 6 months later to see if there was any change in the satisfaction results

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label
